--nabana no sato is not a bad place to visit, but it's not really a "must" sort of place either. the park itself is about an hour outside central nagoya;
--if basing yourself at kyoto, with so many day trips planned, it's best to pick a base within a 5-minute walking radius of kyoto station;
--if you have concerns dragging bags while moving around, use luggage forwarding strategically. your bags will go between hotels door-to-door. delivery is next day (except to the airport which requires 2 days) so you will need to use overnight bags in between;
--green car is good but it's not vital. ordinary car seats are much more comfortable than an airplane's economy seat.

column5:
#30,
hida folk village vs shirakawa-go - have visited both. the former is more akin to an open air museum whereas locals have been living in latter for centuries. for those who could not make it to the latter, the former is indeed the next best substitute.
in takayama old town, also check out the yatai kaikan where yatai used in the annual takayama festivals are exhibited.

there is no tunnel nor elbow turns b/w tokyo/shinjuku and kawaguchi-ko along the chuo expressway - validate on google map. unlike bus drivers elsewhere in europe, most bus drivers in japan are way more cautious and seldom make abrupt stops unless it's necessary. besides, in japan the speed limits are much lower - 50km/h on national roads and less than 110km/h on expressways. on average, it hardly steers faster than 80km/h.
indeed, the train option is a viable alternative, though bus ride is comparatively benign. only you can tell if it'd be bearable. sitting behind the bus driver and taking window seats as suggested by sammy are some good ideas to alleviate motion sickness.
train fares b/w shinjuku and kawaguchi-ko for reserved seats cost jpy4,130. refer to route #1 in the link below.

>>and, of course, with my leaning towards so many trains, it might make it more cost effective for us to get the jr pass
not really. roughly speaking, the 14-day jr pass pays off if a round trip b/w tokyo and hiroshima by shinkansen (on long distance routes) is taken within 14 days. note that train fares of jr express trains cost much less, such as jr kaiyu or azusa serving the jr chuo line. besides, daily commutes on city subways are not covered at all. thus, the value of jr pass drops substantially while stationing in large cities.
if you depart from osaka/kix, then it's very likely you'd overpay a lot by buying jr pass, which is not cheap.

column5:
please see  . the yokohama port has 3 piers: shinko, osanbashi, and daikoku. shinko and osanbashi are conveniently located within walking distance of the minato mirai redevelopment area. daikoku is not conveniently located. your cruise line may be able to tell you which pier they will use, but the port might reassign the boat closer to the time of your trip.
yokohama chinatown is not that different from san francisco chinatown, but there are plenty of other things to do in yokohama. in the minato mirai area, there's plenty of shopping, the yokohama museum of art, and the japanese overseas migration museum. you can use the street view function on google maps to "preview" chinatown and the minato mirai district. elsewhere in yokohama, there's the sankeien garden. train service (including english signage) from yokohama to tokyo is excellent, although trains are crowded during commute hours. for schedules, see www.hyperdia.com. from yokohama, it would be easy to do a day trip to kamakura. i'm a big fan of yokohama, but if you want to spend most of your time in tokyo, it might make sense to stay in tokyo.
in general, hotels may be cheaper in yokohama than in tokyo. there are a couple of low-priced toyoko inns adjacent to the baseball stadium in yokohama, and there are many other hotels between kannai station and the waterfront.

good morning panchopup
actually, as we so often get questions from people who just want to go to bath, bourton on the water and the isle of skye, it‚Äôs quite refreshing to see one which combines the otherwise oddly disparate destinations you‚Äôve raised.
have you considered buying open jaw air tickets, maybe arriving in scotland and leaving from london? if you did this you could construct a zigzag trip going glasgow, aberystwyth, norwich, heathrow, which, according to a bing map search would, direct, be 729 miles in total. in british terms this is a lot of driving but in three weeks, and as it for a specific purpose rather than random sightseeing, it would be entirely possible. as all of these places have railway stations, you could do the trip by train, with several changes on the way, but a car would give you flexibility and you could take in some interesting sights en route without lengthening your driving overmuch. for instance, close to the direct route from glasgow to aberystwyth there are two wonderful national parks (the lake district and snowdonia) and you could stop over for two or three nights in either or both of these. there‚Äôs also the fine city of liverpool of course, and, for a contrast, the roman/medieval cathedral city of chester. standard advice here is not to do lots of one-night-stands but to pace your journey and get to know fewer places well rather than more places superficially.
aberystwyth to norwich is far from being a ‚Äòstandard‚Äô tourist trip but you could explore the welsh borders en route ‚Äì consider the fine old town of ludlow as a stopover. lichfield is a delightful cathedral city, off the well-trodden tourist track, and cambridge wouldn‚Äôt be a very big detour. norwich itself is a great small city and one which tends to be unjustly missed by overseas visitors purely because of its geography.
all this is obviously exceptionally covid-dependent and i think you realise that the chances of it being possible safely and legally this season are less than evens. bear in mind too that late july and august are high season touristically and i suspect more british people will tend to be holidaying, if at all, within britain rather than overseas. finally, a website called university rooms offers accommodation actually within university colleges and halls of residence outside term time. worth a look if you haven‚Äôt already, although for obvious reasons they won‚Äôt be taking bookings just now.

i believe, since you bunch were tourists who didn't mind waking up as early as 5-5:50 am, had you done that regularly, there were a few spots you could have added to your itinerary, such as manda la (a high-pass at an hour journey from dirang, and locals call 3 sisters mandala, sela, bumla in the region), bomdila war memorial and viewpoint (in bomdila), kalachakra gompa (in dirang), taktsang gompa (4 km from madhuri lake and you had time) etc.

you could have mentioned in your story that you entered arunachal pradesh from guwahati via kalaktang and returned via bhalukpong. i was confused.

"would chiang mai be a good base for 10 days or is it too long? "
yes and no,, depending on what you want to get out of your vacation.
1st, muay thai gyms exist in practically every city in thailand, and your hotel could arrange muay thai workouts at your hotel if you request it.
no, 10 days is too long for chiang mai and any other single destination in thailand for a first-time visitor to thailand, chiang mai is not centrally-located, and does not offer a well-rounded thailand travel experience.
yes, 10 days is adequate if you want to earn a ph.d. in chiang mai. as michaelb stated above, chiang mai provides a good base for exploring the surrounding cities that he mentioned above, especially exploring chiang rai in the north.

column5:
i feel that you are being a bit ambitious to cover so many places in 10 days. the way that your travel is set up you end up travelling between cities and that takes up most of the daylight hours. out of the 10 days, you are travelling for 4 days. also during these times, train and bus schedules are disrupted.

in my view, cut out bikaner and do the circuit the other way, i.e. jaipur-udaipur-jodhpur-jaisalmer. the reason for this is that temple timings at ranakpur means that when starting from jodhpur, you reach kumbhalgarh only in the evening, necessitating an overnight stay there. but doing it the other way (from udaipur to jodhpur) means that you can cover kumbhalgarh and ranakpur on the same day.
also while driving from jaipur to udaipur you can cover chittorgarh.

i was there from november 18, 2020 - february 18, 2019, during my entire last visit. took uber numerous times. the only place i couldn't get an uber was at the cruise port terminal. that's where the taxi sharks hang out. it took me an hour to get a taxi. there were two lines of them waiting and they all said they don't accept credit cards, which is lie. they want cash and hoping you don't have change so they can say they don't have change. they do the same thing in doha on the buses and the taxis. i already know of all the scams so i told all of them they were a fraud because they're all equipped with a credit card terminal that many keep in the center console. i know this because another taxi driver had already told me before.
if you want to know if uber is still there just go to your uber app and put in a origination and destination point anywhere in dubai and see if it shows cars around.
i've been to so many countries and have dealt with so many taxis that i generally stay away from them. but, if you ever have a suspicion with a taxi driver take a photo of their license plate and car number. i've never had any problems with ride-sharing apps (yet). :)

whilst i would usually agree with those that advocate spending 3 nights in a place on the basis that will allow two full days of actually seeing stuff, there are occasions when on a road trip, i would be quite happy moving on each day. sometimes, the journey can be as rewarding as the destinations, especially on a motorcycle or driving trip when you can, and will want to, stop at places along the way.
when we did the trip from mai chau to ninh binh we had planned to spend 3 days in mai chau as we loved it when we first stayed the 15-20 years ago. it had changed a lot. the two homestays that were there back then had multiplied to something like 50. to get the authentic experience you seek, i would suggest getting way out into the valley away from the main settlements. ninh binh needs 3 nights to see the main sights, take a few boat trips etc. . both mc and nb get very busy with domestic tourists especially at weekends so time your visits mid week if possible.
in between the two locations we spent one night at each of three small villages. these one night stays were about right as we were mainly hiking (and part driving) between each. on a motorbike with a guide i can imagine it would be a great experience .
if you can add in some extra days, have you consider the caves in phong nha ke be? well worth tif you can add in maybe three nights en route from hue to ninh binh by train.quite a lot else to do in teh area other than the cave (although they are amazing!)
as for traveling by train, it is my preferred option in vietnam. not the most comfortable but ok i would recommend going for a soft sleeper berth (bottom bunk if you can). my understanding is that the schedules have been dramatically curtailed, when they will return to normal. two benefits of train travel; they are usually overnight and you save on a nights accommodation. most live late evening and arrive early morning effectively allowing a full day at either end.
